justification: The article lists “Retributive justice (Justice Game, punishment…)” when describing the moral dimension and its behavioral economic task.
Experiment 1 states that the Justice Game records choices to “punish by reversing the split,” which operationalizes punitive responses.
The authors note, “we directly tested fairness concerns by exploring decisions to divide a monetary endowment in the Dictator Game.”
During the Dictator Game, selecting the ‘unfair split’ ($1/$0) is used to index selfish behavior, as described in the procedure section.
They categorize “procedural justice (Cheating Game, honesty)” as a key moral dimension and use the die-rolling Cheating Game to capture honest versus dishonest reporting.
In Experiment 3, the Cheating Game asks participants to report die outcomes; deviations from chance are treated as cheating behavior.
